docs/example.html.title: Example program | TableScript
docs/example.html.summary: Example program Here is a program showing virtually all features: // IMPORTANT // In this file, next to print() calls, the supposed output will be shown in a comment along with a commentary if needed //Importing the standard library for print import stdlib; //Table variables tab global = ["h", "e", "l", "l", "o"]; //Concatenation operator +: table concatenation tab greeting = global + [" ", "world"]; print(greeting); //hello world //Dollar strings with full expressions (syntax highlighter migh break because of this) tab doll = $"The message of the day is '{greeting + "!"}'"; print(doll); //The message of the day is 'hello world!' //True and false handled with length: 0 is false, > 0 is true tab true = ["anything"]; tab false = []; //If statements if true{ print("true"); //true } if false{ print("false"); } //String literals are handled like length 1 tables: tab eq = "abcd" == ["abcd"]; //Ternary operator print(eq ? "equal" : "not equal"); //equal //nagation operator !: returns [] (false) when the table has length greater than zero and [""] (true) when length is 0. This is the general concept of truthiness tab t = !["h"]; //difference operator -: removes elements tab h = ["a", "a", "b"] - ["a"]; print(h); //ab //product operator *: cartesian product tab p = ["a", "b"] * ["c", "d"]; print(p); //acbcadbd p = ["a", "b"] * 3; print(p); //ababab p = 3 * ["a", "b"]; print(p); //aaabbb //Equality operators == and != print(["a", "b"] != ["ab"] ? "true" : "false"); //true print(["a", "b"] == ["a", "b"] ? "true" : "false"); //true print(["a", "b"] == "ab" ? "true" : "false"); //false //Reduction operator ^: joins all elements into a single string print(["a", "b", "c"]^ == "abc" ? "true" : "false"); //true //Decomposition operator %: separates all charachters of all elements into their own elements print(["a", "b", "c"] == "abc"% ? "true" : "false"); //true //containment operator @: checks if all elements are contained print(["a", "b"] @ ["c", "d", "a", "n", "b"] ? "true" : "false"); //true print(["a", "b", "m"] @ ["c", "d", "a", "n", "b"] ? "true" : "false"); //false //Comparison operators <, <=, >, >=: they compare lengths of tables print(["1"] > ["a", "b"] ? "true" : "false"); //false print(4 > ["a", "b"] ? "true" : "false"); //true //Numbers are tables as well: 2 is the same as ["", ""], with empty strings and length 2. print(3); //Nothing will be seen (empty strings) print(3 == ["", "", ""] ? "true" : "false"); //true //Element access tab abc = ["a", "b", "c", "d", "e", "f"]; print(abc.0); //a print(abc.1); //b //Negative index: last elements print(abc.-1); //f print(abc.-2); //e print(abc.random); //Random element print(abc[1]); //b print(abc.100); //Obviously out of bounds, returns [] print(abc.-100); //Obviously out of bounds, returns [] //Element setting tab nums = ["0", "2", "3"]; nums.0 = "1"; print(nums); //123 nums[1] = "a"; print(nums); //1a3 //Expression index access with [] nums[1 + 2] = "g"; print(nums); //1a3g //Literal building: flattening of other tables tab all = [abc, "+", nums, ["j", ["k", "l", abc], "k"]]; print(all); //abcdef+1a3gjklabcdefk //length: retuns a number table of the length: ["a", "b"].length => ["", ""] (2); print(2 == ["a", "b"].length ? "true" : "false"); //true //While statements with else clauses(if no break was invoked) tab i = 0; while i < 5{ print("elem"); i += 1; }else{ print("finish"); } //Range access: [index, length]. Handles negative indexes, negative lengths and expressions print(abc[0, 3]); //abc print(abc[1, 3]); //bcd print(abc[1, 300]); //Out of bounds, auto crops: bcdef print(abc[-1, 1]); //f print(abc[-1, -1]); //e print(abc[random, 2]); //random consecutive elements print(abc[1 + ["n", "t"], 1]); //Expression: d //Do statements with optionally else clause i = 0; do{ print("do"); i += 1; }while i < 6; //Visual separator print("next loop"); //next loop i = 0; do{ print("do"); i += 1; }while i < 6 else{ print("finish do"); } //Foreach foreach letter @ abc + nums{ print(letter); } //Grouping with () tab g = (abc + "k")%.length > (16 - (4 + 2)); print(g ? "true" : "false"); //false //Lexical scoping tab k = "out"; if 1{ print(k); //out tab k = "in"; print(k); //in } print(k); //out //Function call print(plusA("h")); //ha //Implicit return print(retNone() == [] ? "true" : "false"); //true //Global var access tab glob = "hi"; print(greet()); //hi //Self function call print(abc.decorate()); //eeeeee //Alternate self funcion call print(decorate(abc)); //eeeeee //Function overloading print(fibonacci(10).decorate()); //eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee print(fibonacci(20, 3)); //text here. lorem ipsum //stdlib includes a function called 'upper' to turn tables into uppercase. However, we declared a function called the same. See what happens when declaring the import: print("j".upper()); //oops print("j".stdlib::upper()); //J print("j".local::upper()); //oops //Complex funcion usage + library functions print(join([getDate()[0, 3].reverse().join("/"), getDate()[3, 3].join(":")], " ")); //Todays date //Exiting the script compeltely(not needed at the end, used for early exit, maybe even in a function) exit; //Functions go AFTER all of the program function plusA(t){ return t + "a"; } function retNone(){ print("hello!"); //Implicitly returns [] } function greet(){ return glob; } function fibonacci(n){ if n <= 1{ return n; } //Recursion return fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2); } function fibonacci(n, k){ return "text here. lorem ipsum"; } //Self function function decorate(self){ tab i = 0; tab r; while i < self{ r += "e"; i += 1; } return r; } //Local function function upper(self){ return "oops"; }

docs/introduction.html.title: Introduction | TableScript
docs/introduction.html.summary: Introduction Using the scripting language without any aditional features is very straightforward: using TabScript; class Program{ static void Main(){ //Get source string src = File.ReadAllText("program.tbs"); try{ TableScript script = TableScript.FromSource("program.tbs", src); script.Run(); }catch(TabScriptException ex){ Console.Error.WriteLine(ex); } } } You can use a custom IImportResolver to add features in the form of imports. We will explore this feature further in the next tutorial

docs/libraries.html.title: Libraries | TableScript
docs/libraries.html.summary: Libraries To create a custom library with external functions, start by creating a static class with static methods: using TabScript; public static class CustomLib{ public static int sum1(int a){ return a + 1; } public static string getDayOfTheWeek(int index){ return index switch{ 1 => "Monday", 2 => "Tuesday", 3 => "Wednesday", 4 => "Thursday", 5 => "Friday", 6 => "Saturday", 7 => "Sunday", _ => null }; } } Because TableScript functions always return Table and take Table as arguments, they need to be converted. For the methods, the valid return types are: void: Returns an empty Table string: Returns a single element table. If the string is null, an empty table int: Returns a n element table (new Table(int)) bool: Returns a 0 or 1 element table (Table.GetBool(bool)) Table: No conversion is done For the arguments, they must be one of the following: string: The table argument is reduced (Table.AsString()) int: The table argumet Length is used (Table.Length) bool: The table truthiness(length > 0) is used (Table.Truthy) Table: No conversion is done Now, add a property to convert to a ResolvedImport. Once this conversion is done, there is no point in doing it again, so we store it in a private field. Also, creating a list with functions and their description will make it easier. public static (Delegate func, string description)[] AllFunctions => new (Delegate, string)[]{ (sum1, "Sum 1 to a number"), (getDayOfTheWeek, "Get day of the week name by index") }; static ResolvedImport compiled = null; public static ResolvedImport AsImport {get{ if(compiled == null){ compiled = Library.BuildLibrary("customlib", AllFunctions); } return compiled; }} As we saw previously, we can use a custom IImportResolver. In this example, we will implement a Resolver on top of the Standard Resolver that can resolve this new library. This is the custom IImportResolver: using TabScript; class CustomImportResolver : StandardImportResolver{ public override ResolvedImport Resolve(string import, string callingFilename){ if(import == "customlib"){ return CustomLib.AsImport; } return base.Resolve(import, callingFilename); //Safely handle anything that wasnt recognized } } Then, we just need the Main method: using TabScript; class Program{ static void Main(){ string path = "program.tbs"; try{ TableScript script = TableScript.FromSource(path, File.ReadAllText(path), new CustomImportResolver()); script.Run(); }catch(TabScriptException ex){ Console.Error.WriteLine(ex); } } } Now, using this CustomImportResolver, we will have acess to sum1 and getDayOfTheWeek: // IMPORTANT // In this file, next to print() calls, the supposed output will be shown in a comment along with a commentary if needed import stdlib; import stdnum; import customlib; //Our custom library! print(sum1(3).toNum()); //4 print(getDayOfTheWeek(5)); //Friday If there is any doubt about the signature of functions implemented in libraries, you can always print them out: Console.WriteLine(CustomLib.AsImport); This prints: customlib export function sum1(a){ EXTERN; } //Sum 1 to a number export function getDayOfTheWeek(index){ EXTERN; } //Get day of the week name by index

docs/multifiles.html.title: Multiple Files | TableScript
docs/multifiles.html.summary: Multiple Files Combining multiple files helps you to organize your code. How can we make it possible? As we saw previously, we can use a custom IImportResolver. In this example, we will implement a Resolver on top of the Standard Resolver that can resolve files and merge them together. This is the custom IImportResolver: using TabScript; class CustomImportResolver : StandardImportResolver{ string path; //Keep the path public CustomImportResolver(string p){ path = p; } public override ResolvedImport Resolve(string import, string callingFilename){ if(File.Exists(path + "/" + import)){ return TableScript.SourceAsImport(path + "/" + import, File.ReadAllText(path + "/" + import), OnReport); } return base.Resolve(import, callingFilename); //Safely handle anything that wasnt recognized } } Then, we just need the Main method: using TabScript; class Program{ static void Main(){ string path = "program.tbs"; //Local path try{ TableScript script = TableScript.FromSource(path, File.ReadAllText(path), new CustomImportResolver(".")); script.Run(); }catch(TabScriptException ex){ Console.Error.WriteLine(ex); } } } When doing this, the functions marked export of the second file will be available for use. Here is an example of a two-file program, intentionally complicated to show what can and cannot be done. // IMPORTANT // In this file, next to print() calls, the supposed output will be shown in a comment along with a commentary if needed import stdlib; //Nothing happens for duplicated imports import "multifiles2.tbs"; //Import the other file. Cyclic imports is not something to worry about tab a = "Hello world"; //Global variable tab b = "Greetings!"; //Global variable print(greet()); //Greetings! print(greet2()); //I have always been ready to greet you print(greet3()); //I have always been ready to greet you print(greet4()); //I have always been ready to greet you print(greet5()); //I have always been ready to greet you print(greet6()); //Greetings print(bye()); function fun(){ return b; //Accessing local variables } export function greet(){ return fun(); //Can access function that isnt export } import stdlib; //Nothing happens for duplicated imports import "multifiles1.tbs"; //Import the other file. Cyclic imports is not something to worry about import stdnum; //Only in this file tab a = "I have always been"; //Global variable tab b = " ready to greet you"; //Global variable print("Welcome!"); //This wont execute. Of the main body of imported scripts, only variable declarations are kept //Returns "I have always been", "ready to greet you" function fun(){ return a + b; //Accessing local variables } //same name as function in other file export function greet(){ return fun(); //Can access function that isnt export } export function greet2(){ return local::fun(); //Accesses local function } export function greet3(){ return greet(); //Accesses the local function, locals are prioritised if unspecified import } export function greet4(){ return local::greet(); //Accesses local function } export function greet5(){ return multifiles2_tbs::greet(); //Accesses local function with its import name } export function greet6(){ return multifiles1_tbs::greet(); //Accesses the function in the other file specifying the import } export function bye(){ //Stdnum is only available in this file if stdnum::greater(stdnum::rand("0", "1"), "0.5"){ print("Sad to see you go!"); }else{ print("Bye!"); } }

docs/stdlist.html.title: StdList tutorial | TableScript
docs/stdlist.html.summary: StdList tutorial Lists are several tables expressed as one, compacted together. Here is a program going over most of the features of stdlist: // IMPORTANT // In this file, next to print() calls, the supposed output will be shown in a comment along with a commentary if needed import stdlib; import stdnum; import stdlist; //StdList tutorial. Lists are several tables expressed as one, compacted together. tab lst1 = ["aa", "a", "aa", "t0e0", "t1e0", "t1e1"]; //Internal format used printLst(lst1); tab lst2 = newLst(); //New empty list lst2 = lst2.addTab(["h", "g"]); lst2 = lst2.addTab(["1", "2", "3", "4"]); lst2 = lst2.addTab([]); printLst(lst2); tab lst3 = mergeLst(lst1, lst2); printLst(lst3); tab lst4 = lst3; lst4 = lst4.delTab(4); lst4 = lst4.delTab(2); lst4 = lst4.setTab(2, "help"%); lst4 = lst4.setTabElem(2, 3, "7"); printLst(lst4); print(lst4.flattenLst().decor()); //Flattened all tables of the list tab lst5 = newLst(); lst5 = lst5.addTab(["b", "g"]); lst5 = lst5.addTab(["b", "h"]); lst5 = lst5.addTab(["b", "f"]); lst5 = lst5.insertTab(1, ["Ã±", "k"]); printLst(lst5); print(tf(lst5.containsTab(["b", "h"]))); //true print(lst5.indexOfTab(["b", "h"]).toNum()); //Helper function function tf(self){ return self ? "true" : "false"; } //Helper function function decor(self){ return "[" + self.join(", ") + "]"; } //Function to print a list function printLst(self){ print(""); //Separator print(self.decor()); tab isLst = self.isLst(); print("Is list: " + tf(isLst)); if(!isLst){ return; //Exit if its not a list } tab len = self.lstLen(); print("List length: " + len.toNum()); tab i = 0; while(i < len){ //Printing all tables tab tablen = self.tabLen(i); print("Table " + i.toNum() + " length: " + tablen.toNum()); print("Table " + i.toNum() + ": " + self.getTab(i).decor()); tab j = 0; while(j < tablen){ //Printing all elements inside table print("Table " + i.toNum() + " element " + j.toNum() + ": " + self.getTabElem(i, j)); j += 1; } i += 1; } }

index.html.title: TableScript | TableScript
index.html.summary: TableScript TableScript is a string-based scripting languange. This library built in C# provides an API to interpret TableScript programs. You can go to the Introduction for starting. You can also check the API for the code usage details.
